title: 106_hr350
content: The Act may be cited as the "Mandates Information Act of 1999". The Congress finds that before acting on proposed private sector mandates, it should consider the effects on consumers, workers, and small businesses. The implementation of the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 has increased awareness of intergovernmental mandates without affecting existing environmental, public health, or safety laws. This Act will enhance awareness of prospective mandates on the private sector without impacting existing laws. The costs of private sector mandates are often borne by consumers through higher prices and reduced availability, workers through lower wages and benefits, and small businesses through hiring disincentives and stunted growth. The Act aims to improve Congress' deliberation on private sector mandates by providing complete information and ensuring focused deliberation on their effects. It also seeks to help Congress distinguish between mandates that harm consumers, workers, and small businesses, and those that benefit them. The Act aims to improve Congress' deliberation on private sector mandates by providing complete information on their impact on consumers, workers, and small businesses. It seeks to distinguish between mandates that harm and benefit these groups. The joint resolution focuses on analyzing the impact of Federal private sector mandates on consumer prices, worker wages, benefits, employment opportunities, hiring practices, expansion, and profitability of businesses with 100 or fewer employees. This aims to provide comprehensive information on the effects of mandates on various stakeholders. The Budget Act of 1974 is amended to specify that a point of order shall only lie under certain conditions. Additionally, the threshold amounts for bills increasing Federal private sector mandates are adjusted. The Budget Act of 1974 is amended to remove references to "intergovernmental" in various clauses. Additionally, thresholds for bills increasing Federal private sector mandates are adjusted. The Budget Act of 1974 is amended to remove references to "intergovernmental" in various clauses and rules of the House of Representatives. Additionally, thresholds for bills increasing Federal private sector mandates are adjusted. Congress exercises its rulemaking power through these amendments. Congress has the power to make rules for the Senate and House of Representatives, which can supersede other rules if inconsistent. Each House has the right to change these rules at any time. SEC. 5. FEDERAL INTERGOVERNMENTAL MANDATE. Amendment to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding provisions related to state legislation, statutes, or regulations. Passed by the House of Representatives on February 10, 1999.
